text: LYNN, asleep, squirms on the bed. She's early thirties, v pretty, thin-bodied. She MUMBLES in discomfort.
is A YOUNG GIRL in the back seat of a station wagon. She plays with a Barbie, shows it toward CAMERA at the people
Someone SHOUTS, high-pitched but distorted in a dream-lik fashion.
Henry, watch out--!
The young girl's eyes move up from her Barbie toward the front of the car--slow, too slow.
EVERYTHING SPEEDS UP, the frame shaking like an epileptic suddenly got hold of the camera.
Only a half-second has passed, but the young girl is now lying sideways on the back seat and her forehead is smear with blood.
She sits up slowly, dazed. Whatever she sees in the front seat disturbs her. Her lip begins to shake, tears welling her eyes.
Something pops into her peripheral vision. She turns.
A CLOWN has appeared in the window next to her. He SHOUTS something unintelligible to her, and then RIPS HIS CLOWN OFF to reveal a bloody skull--
The little girl SCREAMS--
--and Lynn bolts upright on her bed, screaming. She stops immediately as she realizes where she is, but it takes he moment to calm down.
She turns to the clock--it's 5:38.
Shit.
She jumps up and heads for the shower.
Small neighborhood diner. Wooden chairs and small tables. Lynn rushes in and spots JULIE sitting alone. She rushes to join her friend.
I am so sorry--
(friendly ribbing) Sure, whatever it is is so important that you don't want to tell me on the phone, but it's not so important you can't be-- (checks watch) --a half hour late.
I fell asleep--
(pointing at an empty plate) Look! I finished all the chicken fingers. I'm going to have to go to the bathroom and make myself throw up.
Lynn smirks at her friend and sits down.
I need a drink.
She motions for the waitress and orders a glass of red wi
So spill.
(swallows, takes a breath) I'm getting a divorce, Julie.
Shut up.
She sees that Lynn's not kidding and her smiles lowers li a draw-bridge.
What? Since when?
Things have been bad for...about a year now. I guess things have never been that great.
Well...I just...why didn't you tell me?
You know...you're--
Don't even. I'm your friend first. Manager second.

I thought we could work it out. Bert kept making promises and I kept waiting for him to keep them. Guess what I just found out. (doesn't give her a chance) His ex-wife's name is still on the deed to the house. The house I'm living in. He said as soon as I sold my house and moved in, he'd have it taken off. And you know how I found out her name's still on it?
Julie shakes her head.
The internet. I had to find out on the goddamn internet.
She realizes her voice has started to rise in volume, so takes a sip of her recently-delivered wine, and calms her

I don't know if that was the final straw. It was everything. Julie, I don't know anything about him. I don't know how much money he makes because he didn't want us to have a joint checking account. He always says he's working late at night but he won't give me a number to call other than his cel phone. And that place...it gives me the creeps.
It's a sanitarium. They do that.
(shrugs, moot point) I told him I was leaving and that I was taking Nicky. He hit me.
Julie is shocked.
He...hit you?
(nods) I was packing some things. I said I was taking Nicky and I'd be filing for a divorce. He hit me in the back of the head.
Did you call the police?
No. I just wanted to get out of there. That was a month ago.
You separated a month ago and didn't tell me?
I didn't want to bother you, what with all the stuff you've already got on your plate...
She stops as she sees the look on Julie's face; How Ridiculous.
So what are you going to do?
Get the divorce. Once I get full custody of Nicky, I'll start trying to reassemble what's left of my life. In California.
You're going to move?
I told Phillip yesterday. I didn't tell him why.
How'd he take it?
He was shocked, you know, at first. But he was very supportive as always.
Julie pulls out her cel phone and starts dialing.
Okay, the first thing I'm going to do is cancel the exhibit tomorrow night--
Nononononono, please Julie.
Julie reluctantly hangs up.
You've worked so hard, and to tell you the truth, it'll be good to meet some new people. Take my mind off.
Lynn. We'll just postpone it. I don't think it's a good idea for you to be doing an exhibit when you've got this much on your mind.
It'll be good. No, great.
You sure? Really sure?
Really.
Where are you staying?
A friend of mine is out of the country for a couple months. She said I could stay at her house until I find someplace of my own.
What about Nicholas?
Every other day. The lawyers had a temporary agreement drawn up.
In this state, you'll have no trouble getting sole custody.
(nods) I'm not worried about that. It's just...this can't be my life, Julie. I can't be a divorced mother. I just, I can't.
People change, Lynn.
(wistful) I don't think I ever really knew him in the first place...
The moon casts a faint light through the window. Lynn is asleep in her bed, this time without the nightmares.
looks down upon her, and for a moment there's the impress that someone is in the bedroom standing over her. But the
MOVE slowly across the bed toward the window, passing the nightlight plugged into the wall panel, right up to the window and
into the dark night. We get a nice bird's eye view of the street.
Pools of black shadow lie everywhere. The houses along th street are all dark grey shapes set against a starless sk Each house appears very middle-class suburban.
All is quiet. Still.
Across the street from Lynn's, SOMETHING MOVES FROM UNDER SHADOW OF A TREE.

Still hidden in the darkness under the leaves, it's impossible to tell what it is. Then THE CLOWN moves into light and we can see he's got some sort of bag in his han The streetlight above catches him in total silhouette, so it's impossible to tell much about him. And yet, there's something definitely sinister about him. it the peculiar sight of a clown standing in a deserted street in the dead of night? Or something else...?
The clown scans the houses across the street and his gaze stops at the house two doors up from Lynn.
He turns to look directly at Lynn's house, and makes a shrugging motion, very much like, "What can I do? My hand are tied."
He moves across the street, taking a new grip on whatever in the bag, and the bag falls into the street.
He holds a giant axe. Even in the dim light, the silver a blade gleams like mercury.
Silently, the house awaits his entrance. Taking his time, moves toward the door.
Lynn rushes out of her house, clearly late for something. stops in confusion as she sees five cop cars and an ambul in front of the house two doors down.
A good bunch of the neighbors--moms and kids--stand about groups, pointing and asking questions. Lynn goes over to neighbor, GALE, a chubby motherly type who's shaking her without realizing it.
Excuse me...I'm house-sitting for Margaret. Could you tell me what's going on?
(tsks) Oh it's just awful. If we're not safe here, where on earth can we possibly move to?
She tsks again, but otherwise isn't forthcoming.
Do you know what happened?
The Olsons. All of them. Killed while they slept.
Killed?
Butchered, from what I hear. (off Lynn's look) I know. How could something like that happen here? While we slept? This is a nice neighborhood.
My god...
She breaks it off and shakes her head.
DETECTIVE PETERS, a young guy who looks more like a rock incognito, wanders over with a pad of paper.
Morning folks. You all know the Olsons?
Of course. Who are you?
Sorry. (flashes the badge) Detective Peters. Homicide, of course. Either of you happen to hear or see anything unusual last night?
Why yes. (Peters is interested) There was a carfull of raving psychopaths parked in front of the house about midnight, but I figured if we left them alone, they'd go away.
Detective Peters is put off by the sarcasm coming from someone who appears so motherly. He looks to Lynn, who sm uncomfortably.
Maam. I need to know if you saw anything out of the ordinary last night, or heard anything.
Don't you think I'd have called the police in that case?
Maybe. Maybe not. It might not have struck you as strange at the time, but maybe now, with what's happened...
What exactly happened?
(not particularly sympathetic) Your neighbors have been murdered. I can't tell you any more than that right now.
He hands them both a card.
If something comes to you, give me a ring huh?
That's all? That's all the questions you're going to ask?
Oh hey. Sorry. Did either of you happen to kill the Olsons?
Gale is not amused. Lynn's watching them carry a bodybag a stretcher out of the Olsons' house. Something about the sight has trapped her gaze.
(didn't really need an answer anyway) Okay. Thanks. One of my guys will be over to take your names.
Detective? I'm sorry, I'm already late. (she digs in her purse and pulls out a card) This has my name and cel phone number on it. I'm...house sitting here for the next couple of weeks.
(looking at the card) An artist, huh? You don't much look like an artist.
Says the rock-star detective.
Peters spares her a glance, but ignores her. The way Lynn stumbled over the half-lie seems to have caught the detective's attention.
How long you been...house sitting?
About four, no, five nights.
(nods his head) I may have to come by later and ask you a few questions, Miss... (checks the card again) Blodgett.
Sure, I understand. (beat) Oh, no! I'm sorry, I've got an exhibit tonight, so I won't be back at all today. Tomorrow should be fine though.
Why don't you leave her alone? Do you think she did it? Is that what your keen detective mind is telling you?
The detective turns a bemused smile on Gale.
Wow. You're Miss Cleaver on the outside, but the inside's a real bitch, ain't it?
Ex-cuse me?
I guess I'm not so good with the sarcastic reh-par-tee.
He stumbles over the word like it's too hard to wrap his tongue around, but there's a quiet intelligence in his ey An intelligence that just filed Gale under "B" for bitch.
He wanders off shaking his head.
His superior's going to hear about this.
(rushing off) Well, it was nice meeting you, I'm really really late now.
(calls after her) I'm Gale. Gale Wroten.
Lynn waves back without looking and hightails it to the c
The gallery looks new. Shiny hardwood floors. Small rooms showcase paintings on the wall, with new wave furniture awaiting the pretentious ass of some wannabe art critic.
Lynn rushes in. AMANDA, 23, steps out with a clipboard. S cute in a mousy, Lisa Loeb kind of way.
Lynn, hey.
Sorry I'm late. You'll never believe the morning I'm having.
No worries. Everything's going pretty hokay. OOPS still hasn't delivered two of the pieces, but everything else is here.
Phil around?
Yup.
As if he heard, PHILLIP REID rounds the corner. He's kind faced, late thirties, dressed in an old-fashioned brown suit-and-vest. He's got the makings of a slight gut.
Lynn, some of these new pieces are amazing! You've been doing great work lately. Fabulous stuff.
Thanks, Phil. And thank you so much for this.
It's my pleasure. (takes on an aristocratic air) You know how prestigious it is to once again be showcasing the great Lynn Blodgett at my gallery.
Oh, please.
If Picasso were still alive, I'd turn him down to get you.
Ass kisser.
Well, thanks. It means a lot to me.
What do you think? Should we expect a crowd tonight?
I think you'll be pleasantly surprised...
On Lynn's questioning look...
Same place, plus a hundred people. No one speaks loud. It all QUIET MURMURS over wine or mixed drinks.
Lynn's standing against a back wall with Amanda. She look dazed.
(quiet) How...on earth...did you get all these people here?
WWW dot I hate clowns dot com. I posted it on their message board.
But...if they hate clowns, why would they come?
It's a love-hate thing.
Lynn shakes her head; she doesn't understand, but who's complaining?
She touches Amanda's arm to signal that she's moving. She begins to weave aimlessly among the people, pausing just enough to catch whether they like her stuff or not. Most to.

not as crowded as the main room. A COUPLE murmurs about t painting in front of them, while across the room is TUCK, He's dark-skinned Latino, dressed like a model. He's star deeply at one of Lynn's clown paintings.
She sidles up, trying to be sly.
So what do you think?
(spares her a quick look, then back to the painting) I'm not an art critic or anything...
Who is?
(nods, then back to the painting) It's okay. I don't know what the clown fetish is all about--I think the artist has issues.
Lynn smiles. Not what she expected to hear.
(good-natured) Oh?
Well...they're clowns, for chrissakes. But hers are all so...scary.  Did you see the one where you walk in? I think I remember that one from Stephen King's It.
Lynn smiles. She's looking forward to embarrassing him wh she introduces herself.
But you're no art critic.
No. Tucker Flynn. My friends call me Tuck.
He extends his hand.
Lynn--
--Blodgett, I know. (mischievous smile) I saw your picture in the program.
She smiles and reappraises him.
I didn't want to blow your cover. Not right away anyway.
So what do you really think?
They're good. I mean...they're great. (the smile returns) You've still got issues, but...I think they're phenomenal.
She can tell he's sincere about his appreciation. She's touched.
Thanks. You from the web site?
Web site?
Oh, nothing. What made you stop by tonight?
This is the best gallery in Baltimore. I've bought a couple of pieces here.
Anything of mine?
No. Honestly, I never noticed your stuff before, but I'll definitely be keeping my eye out now.
There are serious looks going on between them, a quick chemistry that seems to be catching Lynn off guard.
Well...I hope you have a good time.
She starts to move off.
Hey. You wanna-- (shrugs) --maybe go out and get a drink later?
Uh---
Is she searching for an excuse or thinking about acceptin She's married, she can't be going out on dates.
It's just a bad time.
He smiles his understanding.
Sure. No problem.
She turns to move off.
How 'bout tomorrow?
She stops.
It's complicated.
Oh.
I'm married.
(sudden understanding) Ooooh...
I mean, I'm separated.
(no problem then) Oh. Great. I mean, not great like I'm happy about it--- (realizes he's screwing up) Hi. I'm Tuck. I'll be right back.
He heads over to the nearest tuxedo's waiter and grabs a champagne glass. He holds it up to toast Lynn, then DOWNS in one swallows.
Then he grabs two others off the tray and returns to Lynn.
I thought if it didn't cost too much, I could get a guided tour of your work.
Lynn smiles at his persistance. There's something immatur endearing about him. His smile is contagious.
She takes the drink.
I could probably put it on your tab.
Tuck's glad she's going along for the ride. He steps up t the painting in front of them.
Take this one. I notice that this clown seems to be in a lot of your paintings. What's the significance?

The more astute viewers will recognize the clown as the o from the dream in the beginning. In the painting, he's staring out at us with a look of sinister intent. He's in stark white hallway with strange objects on the wall. She stares at it intently, as if she's never seen it befo as if she's falling into it.
An excited Amanda pops up behind her, saving her from answering.
Boss. The mayor is here.
The mayor? Of the city?
No, of Sesame Street. (notices Tuck) Who's the hunk?
Lynn's still shocked about the mayor thing, but not so mu that she can't be embarrassed too.
Sorry. Tuck, this is my number one cheerleader, Amanda. She created my web site and does all my other promotion for me.
Tuck smiles at her ga-ga expression.
Nice to meet you.
Um hmmm. I'd like to shake my bon bons all over your--
Amanda. Go tell Phillip I'll be right over.
Okay.
She gives Tuck one last lascivious look, and then she's o
Sorry about that.
It's flattering.
I guess I should go say hi to the mayor.
Is he really here, or is that just a ploy you two use to impress people?
I think he's really here.
Impressive. Can I get your autograph later?
Sure. Hang around. I'll be back.
She gives him a fleeting smile and walks away. As soon as back is turned to him, she makes a face. What the hell is doing?
And then her expression turns to dismayed shock.
BERT, her soon-to-be ex-husband, rounds the corner, a win glass in hand.
Lynn! There you are.
(quiet) What the hell are you doing here?
What? What's the matter?
Who's watching Nicky?
He's in great hands, don't worry.
So why are you here, Bert?
I came to see your new exhibit, of course.
Bert. What the hell is wrong with you? We're not friends. (as if he's forgotten) You filed for divorce.
Only because you were going to.
We're not doing this here. Please leave.
Don't get all apoplectic on me. I didn't realize you'd get so upset.
Why wouldn't I? This is an important night for me.
All right. I'll go.
Thanks.
He takes a final sip of his drink before putting it down.
I'll call you later.
He's gone before he can see the look of disgust that cros Lynn's face.
She takes a calming breath before she goes looking for th mayor.
The crowd is mostly gone. Lynn's walking through room aft room. She's looking for Tuck, but trying not to act like
Room after room(and blank spaces reveal that the gallery successful in moving some of her paintings) and no Tuck. She's starting to get discouraged.
She comes back around to the front counter and there he i talking with Phil. Lynn suppresses a smile.
Here she comes!
Can I get that autograph now?
He lifts something from the counter that was hidden behin his body. It's one of Lynn's paintings.
But...that's...
Your new admirer just purchased your most expensive piece, my dear.
That's eight thousand dollars...
And worth every penny. When it's worth two-hundred grand, you'll beg to buy it back. (to Phillip) Go ahead and wrap it up. I'll get her to autograph it once it's hanging up in my house.
Phillip doesn't get it for a moment. Then he sees the blu on Lynn's cheek. He gets it.
Oh. Oh...of course.
He begins wrapping as Lynn and Tuck exchange looks.
Do you mind me asking what you do, Tuck?
Wanna see?
(playful flirting) I think that would depend on what it is you do.
I'm just, uh, I've got to get some tape from the other room.
Clearly uncomfortable with their flirting, he goes into another room.
Seriously. You want to see what I do, my office isn't very far away.
Okay. But only because you just paid my rent for three months. (louder toward the other room) Phillip, I'll be back soon. I'm going to see Mr. Flynn's office.
Tuck escorts Lynn outside and opens the passenger door of Porsche. He shuts the door after she pulls her legs in.
in the shadows of an alley stands a man. He watches as Tu gets in the Porsche, starts it and drives away.
As it exits the scene, the man steps forward to watch its progress. We see it's Bert, a menacing scowl on his face.
Tuck lets Lynn into the office. She takes a look around a goes to the alarm and turns it off. The office is very ni Clean, well-organized, tastefully decorated.
This is my office.
It's big. She walks down the hall, Tuck following behind indulging her whim to lead.
So...what do you do?
Look at the pictures.
She's been walking by the pictures on the wall, but now s stops to take a better look. The pictures seem to be of elaborate roller coasters at various theme parks.
I still don't get it.
My company designs roller coasters. Disney, King's Dominion, Busch Gardens, you name it. I've got a coaster there.
Lynn's impressed.
How old are you?
Old enough to pick touch football over tackle.
Why don't you want to tell me?
How old are you?
(smiles) Touche.
She's peering close to one picture. It shows some crazy sumbitch standing on the highest point of a tall roller coaster, no car.
That's me.
No.
She looks closer. It's a far off shot, but it sure looks it could be him.
Every time they finish a new coaster of mine, I like to stand at the highest point.
You're out of your mind.
(shrugs) I'm a thrill seeker, what can I say?
The playful smile never leaves his face. She's clearly am at the guts it takes to do what he does.
Tuck leans in close over her shoulder as she stares at another picture.
Impressed?
She's not spooked by how close he is. She doesn't want to on that she's impressed though.
I don't really like roller coasters.
He's non-plussed. He moves past her down the hall toward exit door.
How do you feel about...

He opens the door and flicks on the light. It's a giant g room. A pool table in the center. A twenty foot shufflebo game to the side. A big screen TV in the corner with a so in front of it. A refrigerator, the works.
...shuffleboard?
She follows him into the room. It's getting harder and ha to hide being impressed.
Can I get you a beer?

He's at the fridge. Lynn has a moment. Put a halt to it r now, before it all gets out of hand. The reasons are many the middle of a divorce, Tuck is younger than she is, she got a kid. She doesn't even really know this guy.
Sure.
(as he's getting them) So how'd you get set up at the gallery?
Oh, Phillip owns it.
Seems awfully young to own an art gallery, doesn't he? I picture gallery owners as, you know, over fifty.

He inherited it when his parents died. (sheepish) It seems funny now, but I actually met him...on the internet. An art forum. When he found out I was in the same city, and a painter...he offered to take a look at my stuff.
I guess he liked it.
(nods) We've had a bunch of showings, but none went like tonight.
For a second she looks like she thinks she shouldn't have said that. She breaks eye contact, but quickly looks back smiles.
So how about a game of pool?
Tuck locks up the office behind them as they leave.
Not to sound sexist, but for a girl, you're pretty good at pool.
Not to sound sexist?
Yeah, that's why I prefaced it that way.
From around a bush steps a MUGGER. He's mean-faced and al All business.
Gimme your money.
Tuck moves protectively in front of Lynn. The mugger's no intimidated, more interested in Lynn.
Gimme the purse and there won't be no trouble.
Tuck eyes the mugger for a moment, then holds his hand ou Lynn. She gives him the purse.
He tosses it to the mugger, who catches it in his knifele hand. The mugger reaches in, pulls out the wallet and poc it. He smiles a little more confidently.
What else she got?
You got the money. Get out of here.
I think you best run off, loverboy. I'll see her home.
Take the easy score. It's all downhill from here.
The mugger edges in. Tuck pushes Lynn back farther.
(never taking his eyes off the mugger) When you get the chance Lynn, throw a rock at my office window.
The mugger rushes. He feints and slashes across Tuck's stomach. Tuck jumps back, but there's a rip across his sh now.
Holding the knife up, the mugger admires the thin red coa now along one side.
Wanna reconsider, loverboy?
Nothing from Tuck. Still riveted on the mugger.
The mugger takes two steps and jabs the knife. Tuck steps the side, grabs the mugger's hand and jams an elbow into side.

The instant Tuck grabs the mugger's arm, LYNN HURLS HER KEYCHAIN, five pounds of keys, at the office door. It doe shatter the window, but spider-web cracks appear and a LO ALARM BEGINS GOING OFF inside.

When Tuck elbows the mugger, he drops the knife. Tuck use his weight to whirl the mugger away from him, causing him tumble off balance and fall. A METALLIC CLATTER as a gun falls out of the mugger's waistband.
The mugger snatches the gun.
Run!
Lynn and Tuck run off toward the end of the building.

The mugger briefly points his gun at the fleeing couple, something keeps him from firing. He's pissed. He spares o irritated glance toward where the alarm is WAILING, and h runs off in the other direction.
Tuck's car pulls up in front of the house Lynn's staying Lynn, exhausted, doesn't move to open the door right away She stares at the house.
You sure you're all right? I can take you to a friend's house...
I'm okay. You're the one who got stabbed.
Slashed, not stabbed. I've done worse shaving.
Lynn nods absently as if she's not even listening. She reaches for the door handle.
Well...good night.
Hey.
He grabs her arm gently.
I'll call you tomorrow.
She barely nods, gets out of the car and walks to her hou Tuck waits until she's in the house before he pulls away.
Lynn leans back against the front door and closes her eye Exhausted. With the mugging on top of her exhibit, it's j too much. She's ready to drop.
She trudges into the kitchen and pours herself a glass of wine. The PHONE RINGS. She spares a look at the clock--pretty late for a call--a picks up the phone.
Hello?
Behind her, something outside moves past the kitchen wind
Lynn?
Phillip? What are you doing up this late?
A non-rhythmic tapping can be heard coming from somewhere the other room. Like a branch against a window.
You've had me worried sick. I've called ten times since eleven o'clock.
But...why?
You leave the exhibit with some strange man you don't even know, and you wonder why I'm worrying?
You're right. I'm sorry.
Where have you been all this time?
Lynn notices the tapping. She moves into the television r The tapping seems to be coming from outside the sliding g door.
Long story. Long long story.
She can't see anything outside the window, it's so dark.
You'll never believe what happened.
She flicks on the lightswitch next to the door.

The clown stands there revealed in the light. Like Lynn's worst nightmare, like the clown in the painting Tuck poin out, the one that Lynn paints often, the one from her dre His pupil-less eyes, however, are black as night. The soulless eyes of a shark.
He's staring right at Lynn.
What? What happened?
The clown cocks his head and leans closer, his breath fog the glass. Lynn faints, the phone dropping uselessly to t rug.
With a rumble, the sliding glass door opens to the clown' pull. He steps inside the house.
Lynn? Hello?
From the BLACK comes voices. Echoes, distant and distorte
(coming into focus) Can you hear me? Miss Blodgett, can you open your eyes?
as she opens her eyes. Someone's leaning over her waving something under her nose. It's a MEDIC.
You with me now?
Yes...
She sits up with his help.
Do you feel okay? Does anything hurt?
No. I don't think so.
Did you hit your head when you fell?
Lynn sees there's a COP standing behind the medic listeni His presence distracts her for a moment.
Uh...no. I don't think so.
Do you want to go to the hospital?
No. I'm all right.
The medic nods and begins to pack up his things as Lynn m to a chair. The cop steps forward.
So what happened?
I-- (the remembrance floods back) --there was someone standing outside my back door.
Right here?
He points to the sliding glass door which is open about t inches.
Yes.
It was open when we got here.
Lynn's eyes widen. It was open? It--the clown--came into house?
We'll search the house. I don't think anyone else is here though.
How did you know to come?
A friend of yours called. Said he was talking to you on the phone and it sounded like you collapsed. Can you describe the guy that was outside your door?
He was dressed like a clown.
What? A what?
There's a TAP on the front screen door. They look to see Detective Peters letting himself in.
(to Lynn) 'Scuse me a minute.
He intercepts Peters before he can make it over. There's HUSHED CONVERSATION between them ending in a questioning glance to the cop, who shrugs.
Detective Peters comes over and sits down across from Lyn
Don't you ever sleep?
Not so much. You say you saw someone outside?
Yes. Right outside the glass when I turned on the light.
And was he black or white?
He was a clown.
A clown?
Yes.
There was a clown standing outside your window at one a.m.?
(knowing how it sounds) Yes.
Was he lost? Wandered away from Barnum & Bailey's and got trapped in suburbia?
She says nothing, just glares back at him. He purses his thoughtfully.
This a P.R. stunt?
(confused) What?
I know what you do, Miss Blodgett. (off of her "so what?" look) You paint pictures. Of clowns. This some kind of publicity stunt?
Does it look like a publicity stunt?
No. But looks can be deceiving.
(getting mad) That's great. How profound. I'd like you to leave.
No need to be rude.
The cop catches his eye.
The house is all clear.
Peters nods.
I'm just saying, if this is some stunt, it's a serious crime to call the police.
I didn't call the police.
I know, I know. Your friend did. The guy that owns a gallery full of your clown paintings.
He stands up.
I'll be talking to you soon. I've got some other questions.
Lynn doesn't say anything. She follows them to the door.
'Night.
Lynn shuts the door without a word. She stands there, the thoughts running wild through her exhausted head.
Lynn walks in, holding hands with her son NICHOLAS, aka Nicky. He's about five years old.

I need to talk to you, Miss Blodgett. Let's go back to your house.
Since Peters is ignoring him, Tuck physically steps betwe Peters and Lynn.
What's going on?
You want to step out of the way?
You want to talk to my lawyer?
Lynn puts a hand on his arm.
It's okay. (to Peters) I take it this is important?
Very.
Tuck doesn't seem to notice that Lynn's a bit relieved to getting away.
Thanks for a great lunch.
My pleasure. Give me a call later, huh?
I will.
Detective Peters sees her to her car.
Can you tell me what's going on?
Not here.
Nicholas--my son--nothing's--
It's not about your son. Please follow me back to your house.
He heads to his car.
Lynn and the detective enter. As they shut the door we ca see Officer Patrick right outside the door.
Well?
Sit down. Please.
He escorts her into the living room and gets her to sit o the couch.
Amanda Greene was murdered last night.
Her head jerks back like she was punched.
What?
I'm sorry, I know she worked for you.
She's a strong woman. Doesn't want to show her tears, so fights them back.
She was my friend.
It's the only thing she can get out. The tears course dow her cheeks.
There's more. I wish I were better with the tact, but I'm not.
What?

The scene of--where she died...I mean, it's not just that. We don't have the coroner's report yet, but I'd bet my shield that... (licks his lips, probably shouldn't say anything) ...well, I think the person that killed your friend is the same person that killed the family three doors down from you.
What?
She's having a hard time dealing with it. Any of it. Amanda...dead, killed...same as the neighbors...
I don't think it's a coincidence. I think someone is zeroing in on you.
Lynn's too surprised to speak.
I've already said more than I should. But there's more. I need to know I have your complete confidence, that you won't repeat what I'm about to tell you. To anyone.
She nods, afraid to trust her voice.
Amanda fought back against the person. We've recovered blood and tissue from under her fingernails. And...grease paint.
Paint?
She's glancing at her paints next to her easel.
Grease paint. Like you'd buy in any Halloween or costume shop.
I'm sorry, I just, I don't understand.
Peters take a photo out of his jacket pocket, not showing to her yet.
The window that he entered from...
He's not sure how to say it...he shrugs and hands her the photo.
She looks at it, not comprehending what she's looking at. window with a hole in it. But below that, smudged white a a red dot centered below it. Then it hits her. Her eyes w in shock.
She stands up and moves to her sketch pad. She flips it o to the clown--her clown--that she drew the night before. holds the picture next to the sketch.

It's pretty obvious that if her clown were real, and he pushed his face against a window, it would leave those ma White forehead, red nose. Evil. Peering in Amanda's windo Just like he peered in her window.
She holds the sketch and the photo out to Peters. He take them, but it's like he already thought.
I admit that I didn't take you seriously with your clown story the other night.
To tell you the truth...I'd convinced myself it was some hallucination, or shock from being mugged.
Well, you have my assurance that I'm taking you deadly serious now.
Thank you.
This what he looked like when you saw him?
Yes.
His eyes are black like that?
Yes.
Huh. Can I have this?
Yes.
He stands, starts backing his way to the door.
Whoever this guy is...we'll get him. You need to watch yourself until we do though. I'll have someone out in front of your house at all times.
Lynn stays strong, nods.
I'll call you if I come up with anything.
Once he's gone though, the tears flow. She weeps almost silently for her friend.
A car is parked under the shade of a tree. Bert's SAAB pu in next to it, but during the conversation, the person in other car can't be seen.
Bert rolls his window down. He tries to act like he's watching something in front of him while he talks.
What the hell is taking so long?
You don't want to take that tone with me.
The man's got a dangerous voice. Bert backs off.
It was--you were supposed to have done it by now.
Clearly, there's been a problem.
And what is that?
First, the guy she's been hanging out with. I could go around that. Other problem, well, it's a clown.
What?
There's a clown been following her.
A clown?
For a shrink you don't hear so good.
Tell me about this...clown.
Only saw him once. Your wife and her new beau went sightseeing at an abandoned amusement park. The clown followed them.
What did he look like?
He looked like a clown. Face paint. Frizzy thing around the neck.
Bert knows something. He stares forward for a moment, debating, but doesn't address it.
So what's the problem?
People are getting killed all around your soon-to-be-ex. The cops are swarming.
What are you talking about?
A family, couple doors down. Then last night, a girl that works for her.
Amanda?
Whatever. My source in the department says they got grease paint off the window the perp came in. (on Bert's clueless look) Like clown makeup. This is gonna take more money.
I don't think so.
Your choice. I'll just take what you've given me as a deposit for services rendered. Have a nice life.
His car starts.
Wait! How much more?
Hmmmm...psychotic clowns, cops galore. Another ten.
Bert winces. He's not happy about it.
All right, but that's it. I can't pay you any more.

head_text.subj: WE COME AROUND SO WE FINALLY SEE HESTON

text: The whole make-it-look-like-a- mugging is out. Get your alibi ready, doc. They're gonna question you.
Heston is the "mugger" who tried to rob Lynn and Tuck.
I'll do it when the money's transferred. She's as good as dead.
His car pulls away. Bert watches him drive off, but his m is on something else. Something nagging at his brain like name on the tip of your tongue.
Lynn enters. All the make up in the world can't disguise fact that she's been crying.
Phillip's at the front desk doing paperwork. He sees her rushes over.
Oh Lynn, I'm so sorry.
He hugs her. She takes a couple of deep breaths, fights o the urge to cry again.
I'm okay.
You sure?
(wan smile) Yeah. When did you find out?
About an hour ago. Some detective came by to ask questions.
Detective Peters?
Yes. That was him.
She shakes her head at his persistance.
(kidding) I think he's been following me.
Phillip's concerned.
Why would a detective be following you?
I was joking. At least, a little. He seems to pop up all the time.
That's strange...Oh, hey.
He retrieves some papers from behind the counter.
I didn't show this to the detective. I hope I won't get in any trouble.
What is it?
Amanda sent us all an email last night.
Lynn looks at it.
It's about Mr. Parrish. His father wasn't just a clown; he was a convicted child molester. One of the children disappeared, but they could never prove he had anything to do with it.
Oh my God...
The second page has some pictures.
Lynn looks. The pictures are from the trial. One picture particular sticks out: Mr. Parrish's father sitting behin the defendant's desk with a deep look of remorse on his f
Feeling overwhelmed, Lynn backs herself onto a bench.
I'm sorry, I should have waited to show you--
No, it's all right Phillip. I have to give this to the police. Amanda sent this to us last night sometime before... (can't bring herself to say it) I have to give this to the detective.
If you don't want to paint for him, I understand.
I have to. I need the money. (off his look) I have to get a new lawyer. Bert's trying to take Nicky away from me.
He can't do that...
He can. (overwhelmed) I just don't feel like I could paint anything right now. I've got cops in front of my house--
The PHONE RINGING interrupts her. Phillip answers it.
Flinner Gallery. Oh, hello Mr. Flynn...
Lynn shakes her head: She's not here.
No, I haven't seen her today. (beat) I'll tell her you called when I see her. Bye bye.
He hangs up.
What's that all about?
(doesn't feel like going into it) I don't feel like talking to anyone right now. (occurs to her) Hey, did he ever buy anything from the gallery before?
Well...I don't think so.
Her cel phone picks that moment to RING. She looks at the number: it's Tuck. She doesn't want to talk to him, but s doesn't want her phone to keep ringing.
She puts up a finger to Phillip to give her a minute, and moves off to talk.
Tuck's leaning against his car.
Hello.
Hey, there you are. I tried to reach you at home and at the gallery.
Yeah, I'm running around...
So, is everything okay? What did that detective want?
Amanda, my assistant...she was murdered last night.
...what?
Someone attacked her in her house.
My God...Did they catch whoever did it?
No.
Is there anything I can do? Do you need anything?
No. No.
Jesus. Why would anyone do that? Do you want me to come by--
No, it's...listen Tuck. (deep breath) I think we uh, I need some time to deal with all this...alone?
He's disappointed, but hides it in his voice.
Sure, I understand. I'm here for you, okay?
Thanks.
You watch yourself, huh? Where are you now?
I'm...outside the police station.
Okay. Give me a call if you need anything. Anything at all.
Okay. I'll talk to you soon.
Okay. Bye.
Bye.
to see he's been standing in front of the gallery looking Lynn's car. He knows she's lying. His expression is hard read.
White cement steps lead down to the basement door. Bert, doing his best to be covert, creeps to the window looking into the basement.
From his vantage through a crack in the curtains, he can THE CLOWN sitting in a chair. The room is very dark, but shape is there.
Bert creeps down the steps and tries the knob. It opens a he slips in. INSIDE, he keeps his back to the door.
(whispered hiss) What are you doing?
The clown's head turns slowly. He looks back to the answe machine on the table, then again to Bert. He stands.
Doc-tor?
Yes. What are you doing, Doug?
The clown cocks his head at an angle. He talks very slow, very stilted.
My name is Shivers. Shivers the clown.
Bert's edgy and uncomfortable. The darkness is pervasive, oh yeah, there's a homicidal clown twenty feet away.
All right. Shivers. What are you doing?
What you told me. Getting better.
(confused) What? No. What you did--Amanda had nothing to do with getting better.
A-man-da?
Yes. The girl you killed. This, what you're doing, I thought we'd talked about it. You've got to stop this. You should come back and start therapy with me again.
You're...confusing me.
He takes a step up toward Bert, who instantly recoils.
Wait. Just...just wait until you hear from me. I'll call you. I'll help you.
Help me get better?
Yes. Just wait for me. Okay?
The clown's breathing heavily.
Yes.
Bert doesn't take his eyes off the clown as he opens the and backs out. The clown watches him go, then sits back d
The phone begins RINGING.
Bert rushes to his car, jumps in and locks the door. He fumbles with his cel phone and dials from his phone book. BUSY.

Damnit! (redials, it's ringing) What the hell do you think you're doing? I thought we agreed using Doug was a bad idea. (beat) Why? Because he's nuts! Yes, that's my professional opinion! (beat) Come on Shane. This, this isn't going to work. I've got--look, this could come back and bite me on the ass. Can you come by my house tonight? Okay.
He hangs up, starts the car and drives off.
Lynn's got her easel set up in front of her while she sketches. There are a number of sketches already set out the floor, but she's not happy with them.
She's got the newspaper clipping of Mr. Parrish's father front of her, referencing it.
Officer Patrick's sitting on the front bench reading Step King's IT. He looks up as a car passes, watches it drive then goes back to his book.
He's parked five houses down across the street. A canvas is on the seat next to him.
Tuck enters, tossing his keys onto a table in the foyer. heads into the living room, picks up the remote from the table and turns to drop back into the couch--
--and he sees the Art Gallery sitting on top of the pile magazines. He goes to it, picks it up, confused. Definite not where he left it.
He flips it open to the marker and Lynn's face stares out him. Then the next magazine below it with another page-ma at Lynn.
He puts two and two together immediately. Mentally curses himself. He grabs the phone and dials Lynn's number.
Lynn paints. Pages of sketches are strewn about her. All forgotten. Her mind is now on one thing, the painting in front of her.
The PHONE RINGS but Lynn pays no attention. She's so focu that she probably doesn't even hear it.
She's immersed in the work. Paying no attention to anythi around her. In the zone.
Officer Patrick zips up as he walks around from the backy where he was apparently taking a piss. A van pulls up in front of the house with PARTY-PLUS on the side.
A HAPPY CLOWN gets out and walks up the sidewalk.
Heston leans forward, very interested in what's going on. wasn't expecting this, but maybe there'll be an opening..
can't believe it--a clown walking up the sidewalk--he fum out his gun and points it at the clown, who doesn't notic because he's reading from a clipboard.
Stop right there!
The clown's startled, just about drops his clipboard.
WOAH! What the hell?
Get over here, get on the ground!
All right, okay--
NOW!
The clown lays down on the ground. Officer Patrick gets o top and handcuffs him.
I didn't do nothin', I was called out here.
Sure you were. You got ID on you?
Inside the suit. You gotta zip down the zipper, in my back pocket there.
From around the back of the house creeps SHIVERS THE CLOW He grips the strings from a dozen floating helium balloon He sees the cop working to get the other clown's ID.
He walks out more confidently, coming up behind the two. cop's got the happy clown's ID out and is looking at it.
Shivers shifts hands, releasing the balloons to reveal th he's been holding his axe, hidden by the balloons the who time.
Through the foyer window, Tuck can be seen starting his motorcycle and PEELING off.
The happy clown, looking over his shoulder back at the co the first to see Shivers. A giant axe in his hands.
Hey...
Patrick turns just in time to see the descending axe blad It takes him in the back of the neck, almost decapitating him. His body falls onto the happy clown who starts hyperventilating.
Shivers spares him a look, then starts to turn toward the front door. As if he has some sixth sense though, his gaz caught on Heston's car.
has his mouth wide open. He's trying to sit very still.
Holy shit...
The clown seems disturbed. From this distance it's hard t tell if he can see Heston, but he seems to be staring rig at him.
Shivers turns suddenly, stalking back the way he came.
The happy clown has his eyes closed, must be going into s or something. Hyperventilating still.
Heston's surprised by the sudden turn and takes a look up down the street. Doesn't see any witnesses. He reaches in his canvas bag and grabs out a cheap rubber clown mask, p it over his head.
He quickly pulls his car in front of Lynn's house. He get out of the car--one hand inside his jacket conceals the g from earlier--and hurries up the front walk.
Past the dead cop and the pinned clown. He runs smack int the front door which surprises him by being locked. He SL his shoulder into it.
Lynn's startled from her work by the BANG against her fro door. She puts the brush down as there's another BANG.
She bolts to her feet just as the third SLAM shatters the lock and blows the door open. Heston moves in fast, kicki the door shut behind him, and stops to listen.
From Lynn's POV, she saw the clown-masked intruder move p the room she's in. She's terrified, but stifles her screa The man is not in her sight now.

She looks around for a weapon, anything, but there's noth no help at all. Heston doesn't wait long. Not hearing anything, he assume she's upstairs asleep. He quickly creeps up the stairs to her bedroom.
Lynn didn't hear him go up the carpeted steps. Quietly sh creeps to the edge of the wall, peers around the corner. not in sight.
Did he go to the kitchen or up the stairs? She eyes the d Ten feet away and closed.
She creeps out quietly, reaching for doorknob, keeping he eyes darting back and forth between the upstairs and the kitchen.
Her hand's on the knob when Heston comes out from the bedroom. His eyes widen inside the mask as he sees her at door.
He FIRES without aiming.
The bullet splinters a chunk out of the door but misses i mark. Lynn SCREAMS and runs toward the back of the house, toward the glass door.
Tuck pulls up on his motorcycle and gets off. He sees the dead cop, the clown pinned underneath him, and leaps off motorcycle.
As he runs to the house there's a GUNSHOT.
Heston FIRES AGAIN and rushes down the stairs after her.
Lynn runs into the sliding glass door, pulls it, but it's locked, she fiddles with the lock--both ways, still won't budge--she sees the stick wedged to keep it shut, grabs i
HEY!
She turns, holding the stick in front of her like a sword She's terrified.
Heston's there, made all the more menacing by his clown m
Nothin' personal, lady. Just delivering a message from your husband. He says goodbye.
He raises the gun level to her head.
TUCK dives into Heston's back, bearing him to the ground. Heston drops the gun to keep from slamming headfirst into carpet.

Tuck struggles to keep control, keep Heston down, but Heston's trying to get up, get some leverage. They're grappling for control, rolling and sliding across the flo like a couple of high-school wrestlers.
Neither one sees Lynn pick up the gun.
In the background RUNNING WATER can be heard. Bert pulls his shirt, then massages his trapezius like his neck is bothering him.
He looks up at the KNOCK on his front door.
He leaves his bedroom and heads for the front door. He lo through the peephole, sees no one, then opens the door.
There's no one there. There is a van with tinted windows front of his next door neighbor's house. He looks at it, it doesn't register.
He goes back inside and shuts the door, rubbing at his ac neck some more.
He steps into the steaming hot water, lies back. It's a little cramped, but he doesn't seem to mind. He takes a second to let the heat soak into his muscles.
Then he reaches over the side of the bathtub and grabs hi book. We can see that he left the bathroom door cracked o slightly.
He relaxes, getting into the book. There's a CREAK from r outside the bathroom door. Bert lowers the book and looks toward it.
It must be his imagination, but the door looks like it's a little farther. He goes back to reading. Turns the page
There's another creak, but this time there's something different. Without lowering the book, Bert can feel it.

There's a pregnant moment where he looks like he's not go to lower the book and look. But he finally does. The clown stands in the bathroom doorway, the axe in hand Bert looks like he's just run into a bear and doesn't kno whether to run or play dead.
Now, hold on a minute--
The clown rushes him, jabbing the axe point viciously int Bert as he tries to get up.
Blood mixes into the water as the clown continues to stab stab, stab.
Heston jabs an elbow at Tuck's head. Tuck turns his head still takes it in the cheek hard. It's enough to let him out of Tuck's grasp. He turns to run--
--Lynn, a distant look in her eye, stands there pointing gun at him.
Tuck stands up.
Lady...you don't know how to use that.
Famous last words. Lynn pulls the trigger. Glass shatters behind Heston. He turns to look and sees a ruined picture featuring a bullet hole.
He turns back to her and smiles but the smile dies as he feels something on his chest. Blood is soaking his T-shir
Heston has enough time to realize he's in a direct line between the picture and the gun, then the life fades from eyes. He collapses sideways.
Tuck is shocked. Lynn can't seem to get her eyes off of Heston's body.
Lynn. Give me the gun.
She turns her eyes from the dying man to Tuck. Their stra lack of depth gives Tuck cause for concern.
(reassuring) Lynn.
He holds his hand out. After a moment, she hands him the

Police cars are clustered in front of the house. Lynn and Tuck stand off to the side trying to stay out of the way. There's an uncomfortable distance between them that Tuck' trying to figure a way into.
Hey...listen, I wanted to explain about the magazines.
He hopes she'll say forget about it, but she doesn't. He on.
I've been a big art fan for years, all kinds, and I first saw your art in those mags. When I heard about the showing downtown, I thought it would be neat to see some of your paintings up close.
You said you saw my picture in the program.
I did. That's just not the only place I saw your picture. I didn't want you to flip out and think I was a stalker, which...is probably what you're thinking right about now.
Lynn's noncommittal. Detective Peters comes out of the ho and heads over to them. He pulls Lynn away from Tuck so h can talk to her privately.
Well. Helluva shot, Miss Blodgett. He's pretty dead.
Good.
Remorse. I like that. It seems your husband paid that guy to kill you.
For a detective, you have the shittiest people skills I've ever seen.
Thanks, I've taken classes.
Why would Bert do that? He's divorcing me, he's taking everything--
I'll make a wild guess and say he's got a sizeable life insurance policy out on you.
Oh. Oh my God...
Yeah. We found a tape recorder in Mr. Hitman's car. He'd taped a few conversations with your husband, conversations where your husband hired him to kill you.
No...
Yep. Plain old greed. I guess getting the hitman to dress up as a clown must have been him being creative. Hell, it's as good a disguise as any.
But he wasn't the clown I saw--
He probably changed outfits.
I don't think so.
Are you positive?
She thinks. That night on the porch, it happened to so fa it was dark and she fainted...she just can't be sure.
He had makeup on when I saw him.
Probably figured out a mask was much less work. Easier to take off.
He's got his mind made up and he's starting to convince h
Why didn't he kill me that night then? After I fainted?
Maybe he got scared off by your friend on the phone. We'll never know for sure. (waves it off) You just take it easy. We're looking for your husband now.
You don't know where he is?
We think he's on the run. No sign of him at his house. Don't worry about it, we'll get him soon. Whatever you were asking for in this divorce thing...ask for more. You'll get it.
She nods, realizing the implications for her and Nicholas way will they give custody to Bert now.
If you have any other questions, give me a call. (hands her a card) My home numbers's on the back. Night or day, doesn't matter.
Okay. Thanks.
He smiles reassuringly and leaves. Tuck comes over.
I heard. I think you should try and get some sleep.
Lynn nods, but looks doubtful.
Can I give you a call tomorrow? When everything's more normal again?
She thinks it over, decides she wants him to.
Okay. I guess I could give you a second chance, seeing that you saved my life and all.
(his smile's back) Great.
He gives her a quick hug, gets on his cycle, and rides of Lynn turns back toward her house and watches the cops, waiting for them to finish their work.
Lynn's in bed again, tossing and turning.
A sterile, white hall, infinitely long. People move in an out of our sight, all blurry, out of focus. As they clear we see a YOUNG BOY sitting on a bench.
He looks at us sadly.
Dead. They're all dead.
He stands up and points a finger at us accusingly.
They're all dead!
THE CLOWN's face pops into view staring right at us, smil like a demon.
sits up in bed, her heart racing. Looks around, starting get her bearings.
She sees a clown doll sitting on her dresser that wasn't there before. Who could have put that there...? All at once, it begins to turn its head, its eyes glaring malevolent red--
sits up in bed for real this time, looking immediately to dresser. No clown doll there.
She looks out the window; the sun is coming up on a new d
Lynn, Phillip and Mr. Parrish are staring at a painting t is propped on an easel in the middle of the room. Mr. Par stares in wonder.
It's amazing. Simply amazing.
We see the painting. It's the one Lynn was working on of Parrish's father, and it captures the look he wanted, to perfection. Tears appear in his eyes.
It's even better than I could have imagined. I can't thank you enough. (to Phillip) Please. Wrap it up.
Phillip takes the painting off to wrap it. Mr. Parrish pu his checkbook out and begins writing. He finishes, signin his name with a flourish.
What was the final price agreed upon?
Twenty thousand.
Mr. Parrish nods, he knew. He hands her the check. She ta it without looking at it.
I'll spread the word about your talent, Miss Blodgett. You have quite a future before you.
Thank you.
Mr. Parrish walks to the front door to where Phillip is waiting with his painting.
Good day.
He takes his painting and leaves.
Wow. Home run, Lynn.
She smiles, looking at the check.
I can sure put this to-- (frowns, then blinks) Oh my God.
What?
This check is made out for a hundred thousand dollars. He gave me a hundred grand.
The PHONE RINGS. Phillip gets it.
Hello? Mr. Flynn?
He shoots a questioning look to Lynn. She nods and reache for the phone.
Hold on please.
Hello? Pretty good actually. A hundred thousand dollars good. (beat) I'll tell you later. (laughs) Thanks. Uh...well, convince me.

Phillip is busy in the kitchen making what looks to be an elaborate meal. He checks in one of his cabinets for nood none there. He begins to go downstairs to get some but something in h backyard catches his eye. There's someone out there stand in the shadow of a tree.
Phillip frowns. From his vantage it's hard to see anythin
He goes back the way he came, through his hall, into his bedroom. Looks out the back window.
He's got a slightly better view, but it's still not great The person almost looks like...a clown. Phillip draws bac away from the window, frowning.
He walks back into the hall and turns into the guest room the corner of his house. One window faces the backyard wh another next to it faces the side of his house. He looks the backyard window.
Has to blink once. The clown is gone. Unless...Phillip tr to peer around to see if the clown is behind the tree, bu doesn't look like it.
Phillip leans back again and doesn't see the clown starin the side window at him.
He turns to leave as the clown raises the axe, swings it the window. On the axe crashing through glass:
Tuck escorts Lynn into the theater. It's huge, covered wa to wall in advertisements for movies.
Nice theater.
Only the best for you.
Will we be able to get popcorn?
With butter. And a Coke.
He winks like, I got the hook-up.
JEFF appears at the top of the stairs leading to the seco level.
Hey Tuck! I'm about ready. You're gonna be in theater eight.
Great. Thanks. We're gonna grab some concessions.
I can send Bobby down to do that.
No, that's cool. I know where everything is.
Help yourself.
He jogs back to the projection booth, punching the code t get through the door.
Tuck motions Lynn to follow him behind the concession boo
A thin set of concrete steps runs down to a steel door, a bathed dimly yellow by the auxillery lights.
The clown makes his way slowly up the steps. The giant ax one hand. A canvas bag in his other hand, THUMP THUMPING every step.
Something short and thin is inside the bag, and it's not moving. Something that looks like a small body...
A bucket of popcorn sits on the counter next to the soda fountain. Tuck is filling two cups at the same time.
You're like an expert. If I didn't know better, I'd swear you've done that before.
Burger King when I was in high school. It's a lost art.
You know, I worked at a theater when I was in high school. Didn't last two months.
They don't know what they lost.
He lets off of the taps at the same time. Both sodas are identically filled. He waits until the foam goes away and finishes filling them.
He pops a top on them and hands her one.
Ready?
(suddenly occurs to her) What are we seeing?
I was thinking some scary horror movie where you'd have to snuggle close to me, but given the past couple of days... (shrugs) I opted for a sappy love movie instead.
Good choice.
They head toward the auditorium.
Jeff is carrying the reel of film--it's the entire movie rolled together, and it's so big he can't even see around He slides it onto a platter and threads it through the projector.
BOBBY, a pimply teen, pops out of the bathroom and shouts down.
I'm gonna go make sure the doors are all locked up.
Okay!
Bobby disappears out the door as Jeff finishes threading film.

As he stands up, movement at the far end of the projectio booth catches his eye. He squints. It's hard to tell. Small pools of light at ea projector are the only illumination. Most of the room is darkness.
Still...something's off. The shape isn't right at the far
Jeff makes his way slowly toward the end.
He's twenty feet away from the spot when the clown steps of the shadow. The only thing in his hand is the axe, but it's shadowed in the darkness behind a film platter.
(jumps) Hey! (relieved for a moment) Scared the shit out of me.
Then he realizes--it's late at night and there's a clown his projection booth. It dawns on him: Someone's playing joke.
Did Bobby put you up to this?
The clown takes a step toward him.
She'll pay.
This ain't cool, man. You can't be up here. This is--
The clown takes another step, splashing a shaft of light the axe blade.
Woah. (steps back) I'll get Bobby for you.
